summary: This is a forwarded email chain from October 2019 announcing that attorney Brad Edwards will be a plenary speaker at the National Training Institute, discussing his representation of Jeffrey Epstein's victims. It summarizes Edwards' decade-long legal battle, the violation of victims' rights via a secret non-prosecution agreement, and the 2019 court hearing where victims gave statements.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: A nationally recognized trial lawyer specializing in representing victims of sexual abuse and violent crimes. He has represented multiple victims of Jeffrey Epstein for over a decade and filed the lawsuit that led to a ruling that the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Billionaire sex offender who was arrested in July 2019 on federal charges for sex trafficking of minors in Florida and New York. He pleaded guilty in state court in 2008 to solicitation and procurement charges as part of a non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: The judge who ruled in February 2019 that the federal government violated the rights of Jeffrey Epstein's victims by failing to confer with them prior to entering into the non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.

persons.name: Brittany Henderson
persons.context: An attorney working alongside Brad Edwards to litigate the next phase of the case to determine the remedy for the violation of the victims' rights.

persons.name: Katy Maskolunas
persons.role: Director of Events and Special Projects
persons.context: The contact person for the National Center for Victims of Crime's National Training Institute event, listed for questions about registration.

connections.description: Edwards served as an attorney for multiple victims of Jeffrey Epstein, providing legal representation and investigating the case for over a decade.
Edwards and Henderson are working together to litigate the next phase of the case concerning the remedy for the violation of victims' rights.
Judge Marra ruled in favor of the legal argument presented by Brad Edwards, finding that the federal government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act regarding Epstein's victims.

events.title: Epstein's State Court Plea and Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty in state court to charges of solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution after entering into a secret non-prosecution agreement with federal prosecutors. The deal was kept secret from victims.

events.title: Judge Marra's Ruling on Victims' Rights Violation
events.description: US District Court Judge Kenneth Marra ruled that the federal government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to confer with or notify Jeffrey Epstein's victims prior to entering into the 2008 non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Epstein's Federal Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested on federal charges for sex trafficking of minors in Florida and New York.

events.title: Closure of Criminal Case Following Epstein's Death
events.description: The criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein was closed following his death.

events.title: Victim Impact Hearing
events.description: More than a dozen of Epstein's victims and their attorneys attended a court hearing where sixteen victims delivered statements about the abuse they suffered, a proceeding Brad Edwards called 'a historic day for crime victims.'

events.title: 2019 National Training Institute (NTI)
events.description: A conference in Denver where Brad Edwards is scheduled to be a plenary speaker, presenting on 'Jeffrey Epstein and the Rights of His Victims.'

locations: Arlington, VA 22210 (mailing address for National Center for Victims of Crime)
keyFacts: Attorney Brad Edwards' involvement with the Epstein case began in 2008 when he represented multiple girls who reported abuse to Palm Beach detectives.
The 2008 non-prosecution agreement between federal prosecutors and Jeffrey Epstein was kept secret from the victims and sealed until after a judge approved it.
In February 2019, a federal judge ruled the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not conferring with Epstein's victims before the 2008 deal.
Despite Epstein's death closing the criminal prosecution, a court hearing was held where sixteen of his victims delivered impact statements.
Brad Edwards and Brittany Henderson are continuing to litigate to determine the remedy for the violation of the victims' rights.
